claim: LazyVim documents an opinionated preconfigured Neovim workflow.
why_it_matters: Defines expected default behavior for comparative UX scope.

claim: Users reported cmdline search interaction breaking with E976 errors.
why_it_matters: Indicates cmdline and integration regressions in real workflows.

claim: LazyVim provides a starter template for user-owned configuration overlays.
why_it_matters: Useful for baseline comparison against starter-style approaches.

claim: AstroNvim docs define modular plugin and feature layering.
why_it_matters: Needed to compare extension architecture and default complexity.

claim: Users reported ARM64 Windows prebuilt binary compatibility failures.
why_it_matters: Highlights platform portability gaps in baseline behavior.

claim: AstroNvim release feed provides explicit versioned change history.
why_it_matters: Supports pinning and reproducible baseline selection.

claim: NvChad positions itself as fast defaults with strong UI emphasis.
why_it_matters: Establishes baseline expectations around visual density and speed claims.

claim: Users reported Telescope previewer regressions.
why_it_matters: Shows navigation and integration regressions that impact daily use.

claim: NvChad default branch strategy uses a versioned long-lived branch.
why_it_matters: Relevant for comparing upgrade and pinning policies.

claim: LunarVim presents an IDE-oriented Neovim layer.
why_it_matters: Useful for comparing IDE-like feature breadth against Jig priorities.

claim: Users reported TreeSitter and Neovim 0.11.2 compatibility failures.
why_it_matters: Shows fragility at version boundaries for language runtime surfaces.

claim: LunarVim documents installation and bootstrap prerequisites.
why_it_matters: Supports procedural comparison for onboarding and recovery paths.

claim: kickstart.nvim is documented as a personal launch point rather than a full distribution.
why_it_matters: Forms minimal-starter baseline needed by WP-15 truth condition.

claim: Users reported scheduled callback runtime errors.
why_it_matters: Demonstrates that even minimal starters can regress under plugin/runtime drift.

claim: kickstart discussions emphasize user ownership and iterative customization.
why_it_matters: Provides additional qualitative signal for minimal-starter expectations.

claim: NormalNvim documents a low-drama distribution objective.
why_it_matters: Expands baseline set beyond top-four distros.

claim: Users reported startup installation bugs for Java test tooling.
why_it_matters: Highlights startup mutation risk and recovery complexity.

claim: NormalNvim exposes release history through GitHub releases.
why_it_matters: Supports version pinning and timeline checks.

claim: LazyVim starter repo provides a minimal seed config for user extension.
why_it_matters: Second minimal starter baseline required for research completeness.

claim: Users reported lock management failures with nil commit values.
why_it_matters: Shows lock determinism risks in starter workflows.

claim: LazyVim installation docs reference starter template usage paths.
why_it_matters: Provides additional procedural source for starter comparisons.

claim: Codex docs describe terminal agent workflows and task execution model.
why_it_matters: Defines baseline for CLI agent capabilities and constraints.

claim: Users reported reconnect loops and stream timeout failures.
why_it_matters: Shows network/session failure class relevant to robust tooling claims.

claim: Codex repository documents open-source implementation details and constraints.
why_it_matters: Provides additional source for policy and architecture comparisons.

claim: Claude Code docs outline terminal-native agent capabilities and setup expectations.
why_it_matters: Needed for baseline feature and workflow mapping.

claim: Users reported command integration breakage in editor extension flows.
why_it_matters: Shows discoverability and integration regressions in mixed IDE/CLI setups.

claim: Reported sub-agent permission inheritance bypass scenarios.
why_it_matters: Directly relevant to policy inheritance controls in Jig roadmap.

claim: Gemini CLI docs describe command and tool workflow surface.
why_it_matters: Establishes agent CLI baseline behavior from official docs.

claim: Users reported confusing always-approve persistence and visibility behavior.
why_it_matters: Maps to approval UX and policy persistence requirements in Jig.

claim: Users reported hallucinated tool-failure diagnostics in CLI sessions.
why_it_matters: Supports need for explicit error provenance and observability.

claim: aider docs define terminal workflow around git and patch operations.
why_it_matters: Relevant to reproducibility and explicit operation comparisons.

claim: Users reported uncaught runtime errors causing command failure.
why_it_matters: Shows runtime stability risks in agent CLI operations.

claim: aider FAQ documents operational limits and troubleshooting advice.
why_it_matters: Provides additional baseline source beyond marketing overview.

claim: OpenCode docs define terminal agent usage and command lifecycle.
why_it_matters: Adds open-source coding-agent baseline with distinct implementation choices.

claim: Users reported Windows startup crashes with runtime assertion failures.
why_it_matters: Cross-platform reliability is central to Jig evaluation criteria.

claim: OpenCode repository provides implementation and issue tracker context.
why_it_matters: Needed as additional evidence channel for baseline behavior.

claim: Continue docs cover editor-integrated agent workflows and policy controls.
why_it_matters: Represents editor-centric baseline distinct from terminal-only tools.

claim: Users reported model API error handling failures in production usage.
why_it_matters: Demonstrates integration and recovery failure classes.

claim: Continue repository exposes changelog and implementation history.
why_it_matters: Provides additional source needed for reproducible baseline context.

claim: MCP intro defines protocol goals and architecture boundaries.
why_it_matters: Protocol baseline anchors vendor-neutral interoperability comparisons.

claim: Users reported schema noise causing agent confusion.
why_it_matters: Shows protocol quality and schema hygiene risks.

claim: MCP security guidance requires explicit consent and boundary control.
why_it_matters: Supports security control requirements in Jig roadmap.

claim: Survey data reports verification burden and technical debt drag from AI-assisted code.
why_it_matters: Used to weight disconfirming evidence against pure speed claims.

claim: METR reports experienced developers can slow down with AI tooling in realistic tasks.
why_it_matters: Disconfirms simplistic productivity assumptions.

claim: Research paper documents measured overheads in AI-assisted workflows.
why_it_matters: Provides peer-reviewed support for conservative evaluation claims.

claim: Security analysis shows denylist-only controls are bypass-prone.
why_it_matters: Supports allowlist-first policy design in Jig.

claim: MCP authorization spec emphasizes explicit consent and delegated trust boundaries.
why_it_matters: Protocol-level requirement for cross-agent safety modeling.

claim: Prompt injection research shows indirect instruction channels can redirect tool use.
why_it_matters: Informs high-severity threat model assumptions.

claim: EMNLP demo paper presents practical prompt injection attack patterns for tool-using agents.
why_it_matters: Adds independent evidence for security regression tests.
title: The Dangers of Indirect Prompt Injection Attacks on LLM-based Autonomous Web Navigation Agents: A Demonstration
why_this_matters_for_jig: Demonstrates indirect prompt injection pathways in autonomous web-agent loops and supports distrust-by-default for tool outputs.

claim: Neovim issue reports nil result edge cases on vim.system wait timeout paths.
why_it_matters: Validates defensive wrapper requirements for shell execution.

claim: Neovim issue reports empty stdout behavior under parallel vim.system calls.
why_it_matters: Supports capture concurrency guardrails in tool wrapper design.

claim: Plugin issue reports wait timeout errors in Neovim 0.11 runtime behavior.
why_it_matters: Confirms ecosystem breakage risk around shell wait semantics.

claim: SWE-bench defines a realistic benchmark of GitHub issue resolution tasks for LLM systems.
why_it_matters: Provides benchmark design constraints for reproducible coding-agent evaluation.
title: SWE-bench: Can Language Models Resolve Real-World GitHub Issues?
why_this_matters_for_jig: Provides benchmark design constraints for reproducible coding-agent evaluation.

claim: SWE-agent studies agent-computer interfaces for autonomous software engineering workflows.
why_it_matters: Supports explicit interface and control-surface requirements for coding agents.
title: SWE-agent: Agent-Computer Interfaces Enable Automated Software Engineering
why_this_matters_for_jig: Supports explicit interface and control-surface requirements for coding agents.

claim: Controlled ICSE study reports that LLM assistance can improve code-understanding outcomes under specific conditions.
why_it_matters: Indicates verification and comprehension effects must be measured, not assumed.
title: Using an LLM to Help With Code Understanding
why_this_matters_for_jig: Indicates verification and comprehension effects must be measured, not assumed.

claim: InjecAgent benchmarks prompt injection attacks against LLM agents and reports non-trivial exploit success rates.
why_it_matters: Justifies mandatory failure-injection tests for tool-routing security controls.
title: InjecAgent: Benchmarking Indirect Prompt Injections in Tool-Using Agents
why_this_matters_for_jig: Justifies mandatory failure-injection tests for tool-routing security controls.

claim: CCS work shows optimization-based prompt injection can manipulate LLM-as-judge style evaluators.
why_it_matters: Demands adversarial tests for judge/tool-selection channels in agent workflows.
title: Prompt Injection Attacks against LLM-as-a-Judge Evaluation Pipelines
why_this_matters_for_jig: Demands adversarial tests for judge/tool-selection channels in agent workflows.

claim: L@S pair-programming study reports semester-scale outcomes comparing human and AI pair-programming partners.
why_it_matters: Introduces longitudinal collaboration signals needed for non-demo workflow evaluation.
title: The Pair Programming Partner Is Better Than You Think
why_this_matters_for_jig: Introduces longitudinal collaboration signals needed for non-demo workflow evaluation.

claim: ICER results show mixed effects of Copilot on student productivity and confidence in brownfield tasks.
why_it_matters: Supports explicit guardrails against false-confidence UX for AI-assisted coding.
title: The Effects of GitHub Copilot on Computing Students' Programming Effectiveness
why_this_matters_for_jig: Supports explicit guardrails against false-confidence UX for AI-assisted coding.

claim: WebInject evaluates prompt-injection attack paths against web-connected agents and reports practical exploitability.
why_it_matters: Motivates explicit capability scoping and tool-output sanitization checks.
title: WebInject: Prompt Injection Against Web-Connected LLM Agents
why_this_matters_for_jig: Motivates explicit capability scoping and tool-output sanitization checks.

claim: SWE-bench Multimodal extends issue-resolution benchmarks with multimodal artifacts and harder grounding constraints.
why_it_matters: Expands benchmark coverage beyond plain text diffs for future comparative gates.
title: SWE-bench Multimodal: Extending Issue-Resolution Benchmarks with Multimodal Signals
why_this_matters_for_jig: Expands benchmark coverage beyond plain text diffs for future comparative gates.

claim: TiCoder analyzes testing inefficiencies in LLM-generated code and reports systematic defect patterns.
why_it_matters: Reinforces requirement for explicit verification burden accounting in scorecard tasks.
title: TiCoder: Detecting Testing Inefficiencies in LLM-Generated Code
why_this_matters_for_jig: Reinforces requirement for explicit verification burden accounting in scorecard tasks.

claim: Trojan Source demonstrates Unicode bidi and confusable encoding attacks that can make reviewed code differ from compiled behavior.
why_it_matters: Justifies strict hidden-unicode detection in CI and editor-level visibility requirements.
title: Trojan Source: Invisible Vulnerabilities
why_this_matters_for_jig: Enforces rationale for hidden Unicode gate hardening and review-path integrity checks.

claim: CodeBreaker shows easy-trigger backdoor poisoning against code completion models while evading strong vulnerability detection.
why_it_matters: Supports treating completion and agent suggestions as untrusted candidates requiring explicit verification.
title: An LLM-Assisted Easy-to-Trigger Backdoor Attack on Code Completion Models: Injecting Disguised Vulnerabilities against Strong Detection
why_this_matters_for_jig: Strengthens candidate-vs-act boundary and motivates adversarial completion regression checks.

claim: USENIX prompt-injection benchmark formalizes attack/defense spaces and shows no evaluated defense is sufficient across tested tasks.
why_it_matters: Supports maintaining explicit policy visibility and disconfirming security evidence in comparative evaluation.
title: Formalizing and Benchmarking Prompt Injection Attacks and Defenses
why_this_matters_for_jig: Anchors WP-15/WP-18 policy and failure-injection roadmap with peer-reviewed benchmark evidence.

claim: Controlled studies show explanations can increase reliance on both correct and incorrect LLM outputs, while sources/inconsistencies improve calibration.
why_it_matters: Supports trust-calibration UX requirements: expose uncertainty cues and avoid confidence theater in agent interfaces.
title: Fostering Appropriate Reliance on Large Language Models: The Role of Explanations, Sources, and Inconsistencies
why_this_matters_for_jig: Maps directly to approval/policy visibility and reliance-calibration requirements in command-first agent UX.

claim: Human vs model attention misalignment explains recurring code-generation errors and reveals review blind spots.
why_it_matters: Reinforces verification-first workflow design and explicit review aids for generated patches and completions.
title: Do Code Generation Models Think Like Us? - A Study of Attention Alignment between Large Language Models and Human Programmers
why_this_matters_for_jig: Supports error-pattern-aware review UX and strengthens requirement to treat model outputs as candidates pending verification.
